column4: ok so I'm a little confused... if, for instance, I want to stop apache from starting by default in any runlevel I should just do...  service apache2 stop && update-rc.d apache2 disable
is that right?
and if it is, then will it remove the actual /etc/init.d/apache2 script or just the rc?.d K and S scripts
also then what is the point of the /etc/default/apache2 option for it not to start?
sorry if this is confusing but the docs are just not clear
It's "sudo update-rc.d -f apache2 remove" if you want to remove it from the startup.  Apache2 and it's startup script are still installed but removed from the runlevels.
is that the right way to manage the services? I mean then what is the point of the /etc/default/jetty having a NO_START option?
or is this just more inconsistency... meaning each package kind of does things differently
If you want to add it back to the startup, do the following:  sudo update-rc.d apache2 defaults
thanks... any insite on the /etc/default stuff?
I'm just trying to understand

/etc/default gives you options for many of the daemons on the system.  Sometimes their entries in /etc/default give you a quick way of disabling the service without removing their startup scripts from the runlevels.
argg ok...
thanks
...but the general method of controling auto start of services is through the update-rc.d command.
